reviews.review: Extremely predictable (you know exactly who the killer is before the movie starts) and poorly constructed live action version of Clue, filled with some of the most ridiculous overacting ever put to screen.
Lots of twists and turns, keeps you guessing
It was ok. Would wait for this one to hit Redbox or Netflix. Not enough humor nor mystery.
One of the best movies I've ever seen -- constantly entertaining, so visually appealing and fun, intriguing uses of time/setting, great characters and acting, and an awesome central story
A great murder-mystery with lots of unexpectedly funny moments. Things get more tense towards the end and there are many twists and turns along the way.
Fabulous movie that keeps you on the edge of your seat until the very, very end!
Started out slow but the twists and turns as the plot developed made it worth the wait. great acting throughout.

One of the best 2010s American films. It's not a pastiche of Agatha Christie any more than, say, BEND OF THE RIVER is a pastiche of WESTERN UNION. It does, however, rejuvenate the whodunnit in a manner akin to STAGECOACH's modernization and modulation on the western. A cross-class group portrait, a social allegory of American heritage (both in the sense of "inheritance" and "the ancestral"), by which are brought to mind the families Trump, Murdoch, etc...

Rian Johnson wanders the house, or the house wanders the movie. It's one of the first mystery pictures in which the production design does not serve merely as a backdrop scrim of 'atmospheric touch.' Johnson doesn't dwell on the house as wealth-porn nor aspirational fetish; just as we are at the brim of projecting our own desires, our property envy, the film shifts to a lower-middle class milieu. 

Final thoughts for now:
- The script and plotting are ingenious. I think RJ said it's a screenplay he'd been working on for seven years. There are no plot-holes or details unaccounted for.
- It's very funny.
- Maybe most movingly, KNIVES OUT and Rian Johnson are earnest enough to imagine the idea of the pure Heroine (cf. Austen, et al) in a modern milieu.

Very possibly a masterpiece.
